instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Can't find the short.
threads.message:
Something around <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> or maybe <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is getting hot. I've replaced both of them.

Also removed and replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>/1 and it's still getting hot in the same area.

No PP3v42 or any power rails really.

It seems to warm up slowly but does eventually get quite hot which is making it hard to pin point what it is.

When I inject power it only pulls about .3 amps.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Can't find the short.
threads.message:
To start, what exact line has the short we're looking for? Based on the chips you've been replacing I think <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

Replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7261</TRANSISTOR> makes no sense at thats for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, which is never going to happen while we don't have <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Can't find the short.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="smiba, post: 25179"]To start, what exact line has the short we're looking for? Based on the chips you've been replacing I think <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

Replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7261</TRANSISTOR> makes no sense at thats for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, which is never going to happen while we don't have <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>[/QUOTE]

I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7261</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> because they were literally sizzling when power was applied.

Short is on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Can't find the short.
threads.message:
I guess it can happen if <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> is stuck open and the controller tries to sink that current with <TRANSISTOR>Q7261</TRANSISTOR>

What S5 rails are you missing or is it only <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>?

If you can't find anything that gets hot you'll have to de-solder some stuff to see if it goes away. First bet would be on <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> itself. if it isn't it can be a lot of things including a internal short :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Can't find the short.
threads.message: I fear this will be extensive damage. 3V42 has nothing to do with anything around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. Only place they come together would be the PCH. <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> heats up when injecting voltage on 3V42? Checked other rails for shorts to GND?
